‚Äú8-Ball - Corner Pocket‚Äù
‚ÄòPool Nation‚Äô is a fun, polished Billiards simulator and a bargain at its $1 pricetag (Steam Fall Sale 2014). Released as the maiden offering from Cherry Pop Games, it‚Äôs gorgeous visuals, multiple game modes, lengthy campaign and lots of unlockables will keep Pool fans coming back for more.

Campaign | Gameplay: Gamers have the choice of playing standard 8-ball or variations like 9-ball, Rotation, Endurance, Sudden Death etc across a variety of visually stunning locations / pool halls. A lengthy campaign mode (against AI opponents) allows you to perfect your game and strive toward numerous unlockables including new locations, pool table decals, new ball styles and cue styles. Additionally, the online mode allows you to match up with friends or other online players in single matches, Tournaments or King of the Hill events. Multiple difficulty levels (from Novice to Pro), a spot on physics engine, responsive controls, and a great soundtrack make this the best Pool game to date.

Flaws: In considering its biggest issues ‚Äì 1. Game Stability is poor (Tabbing to windows results in an insta-crash) and 2. Online Gaming is largely dead (Bring your own friends). Additionally, the developers have pushed the previously promised ‚ÄòTrick Shot‚Äô mode to the next release, and the lack of Co-op play is disappointing as well.

Overall, ‚ÄòPool Nation‚Äô is the best conception of a Billiards game to date and fans of the real game will find this a fun, polished distraction. But, even ardent fans soon realize that Pool without the smoky basement rooms, uneven cues, pitchers of beer, chatty girls, side-bets and bar-room trash talk, is a somewhat hollow experience. reviewText:
Right off the bat, one thing that will catch your attention is the variety of game types.  Most billiards games like to focus only on either 8- or 9-ball.  Those games are here, but they do not stop at that.  Along the game, other games like Rotation and Golf are in the mix.  With nine different ways currently available with Snooker and Trick coming soon, there are plenty of ways to play.

Another strong point about the game is the controls.  Like in any other pool game, being able to control the cue ball is important.  Most games simply allow you to aim the ball and adjust the power.  Even though most games stop at this, there are more options to offer.  By being able to adjust the angle of the cue stick as well as where on the cue ball to aim, it gives the option of doing jump and swerve shots, something most billiard games leave out.  Additionally, with a full tutorial teaching how to do all of these moves, it does not take long before they become second nature.

Beyond all the gameplay details, a nice touch about the game is the amount of customization available.  Even games that try to simulate pro billiards tend to stick to a single, sometimes sponsored look throughout the game.  This one goes beyond the basics.  As soon as you start a game, the highly detailed and moving locals make it feel like you are in what could be a real location.  As you keep progressing, at least a dozen locals, cue sticks, ball sets, and even table decals make it that regardless your taste, there is plenty to see even from a visual standpoint.

Once the single-player game is over, there is still more to play.  Through online multiplayer, it is possible to keep playing with others.  It is even possible to create tournaments to learn who the best player is.  However, the one drawback is that there is no local multiplayer mode available.  This means that in order to play with another person in the same room, the two of you must play through a network.  This feels like a major oversight.  A simple hot seat patch would have made that the game could be a great party game.  Even without local multiplayer, this is still a great package that any billiards fan can easily enjoy.

The difficulties I have with Pool Nation start in the fact that I already know ho to play pool. I will explain: The english in Pool Nation does not accurately represent the way in which a ball would travel with said spin. Top and bottom english when making a cut shot can cause the cue ball to travel more left or right on the deflection, and this is not represented at all.

Left/right english isn't actually as useful on a pool table as an amateur might think. I rarely use left/right english in real pool, as top/bottom english can account for most necessary ball control.

As I can best explain it: Top and bottom english account most for how the cue ball deflects off the object ball, and left/right english effects the way the cue ball deflects off rails. There is a small amount of effect with left/right on ball deflection, and top/bottom on rail deflection, but it is very slight.

This has to do with the fact that the rail is a solid unmovable force, and ball deflection is sympathetic to mass/friction.

My previous pool experience makes this game very unintuitive!

Pool Nation is one of the most polished indie games of 2013- the animations are shiny and smooth, the gameplay is responsive and the physics are realistic. You won't find yourself screaming at this game for bouncing your balls in the wrong direction, or glitching out and dropping your cue ball through the table. With eleven game modes including tournaments, online play, and single-player endurance mode; as well as a slew of collectables to unlock, Pool Nation has no shortage of goodies to keep gameplay fresh.

The single player component revolves primarily around tournaments where you take on AI challengers of ever increasing difficulty. Each match has an associated list of challenges, and completing them unlocks a variety of cosmetic changes like cues and balls. Standard games like 9 ball are present along with more interesting options like Golf, which challenges you to put specific balls into specific pockets. There‚Äôs also a time attack style mode, where balls spawn on the table and you have to sink as many as possible in the time limit. There are Free Play, Versus, and Online modes present too, but I had a hard time finding anyone to challenge online.

Pool Nation is a great looking game that features bright and shiny graphics that makes each game, literally, feel new and different. There are some good themes on the game's soundtrack, and though the game's controls look difficult to use, they aren't difficult to learn. There are also options that can be easily turned on or off to give players assists in a game including arrows that point at the next balls that need to be hit or arrows that show where a ball will travel when hit. All of these features combine to make an excellent presentation for Pool Nation.

But is it fun? In short stints I definitely enjoyed playing the game, but it isn‚Äôt the type of thing I‚Äôd want to play for hours at a time. Having said that, I think Pool Nation is the kind of experience that would be a hit at a house party. If you‚Äôve been searching far and wide for a Billiards simulator, and don‚Äôt have room for an actual table, Pool Nation is probably the solution. The physics are solid, the controls allow for extreme fine tuning of shots, and everything looks super shiny. A few more game types would be welcome, but for $10 Pool Nation is the gold standard in the category.

It makes the grade in the areas critical to this type of game:  the physics are sound,the shot-making is clean, and there's enough variety in the game types to keep things fresh for a while.  On top of that, the game is downright beautiful.

There are some flaws, but nothing game-breaking.  The most glaring (for me, anyway) was that the game feels literally empty.  When shooting, you're shooting in a seemingly deserted hall.  There's no crowd, no opponent squirming in the chair as you knock the balls down.  Speaking of your opponents, while their descriptions are modestly humorous, there's little to differentiate them from one to the next.  At times it feels a bit sterile.  Again, this isn't really game-breaking.  But part of the allure of playing at the bar or hall is the atmosphere, and the game is lacking in that regard.

All in all, though, the plusses outweigh the minuses.  If you're a billiards enthusiast, this game is just about value for money at full price and a bargain if you can pick it up on sale.

reviewText:
Excellent game for a variety of reasons. I like the attention that was put into the details. Everything looks really nice, there are quirky opponents, and most importantly the gameplay is excellent.
There are two campaigns: one for 8-ball and one for 9-ball. Both have challenges each match to help keep the game fresh. Some example challenges are complete a trick shot or have a streak of potted balls. Their are also a variety of opponents with little biographies that you can choose to read or not. It is nice how this game is not too story dependent as I feel that would interrupt the flow. Each campaign takes a while to get through and was fun for me until completion.
Another mode I've spent time on is endurance mode. It is an addicting, time sensitive, mode in which you try to continuosly pot balls while new balls are being added at increasingly fast intervals. I've spent at least an hour just with that mode, chasing a new time record.
The variety of modes is very extensive. There are also one off matches with a variety of rule sets as well as online multiplayer. It is hard to jump right into a match sometimes due to lack of online opponents but there are plenty of small groups on Steam dedicated to tournaments and matchmaking.
Additionally, throughut all the modes, you can choose whether to play with an auto aimer on or off to toggle the difficulty.
The upcoming free update Box of Tricks looks super neat as well. I'm sure it will further increase the replayability of this game.
Overall, for the low price this game is a must buy.

Hey guys, thanks for reading my reviews. Let me make this as plain as possible. If you like pool and can find this cheap, check it out. It's not bad at all. I think the controls are better here in many ways than I've seen in previous PC pool games, but what's the game really like? You get nine ball, eight ball, and a few mini-games. There is a trick mode that hasn't been put into the game yet apparently. The humor is painful mostly, but not always bad. Just never very clever or subtle.

As for the negative stuff: I think it gets repetitious. It's also buggy. I don't like the AI at all, as it sometimes seems too transparent what's happening in the game. Some of the rounds a really good AI player will goof several times in a row to give me a chance to beat it. Other times it feels like it's cheating to win.  Sometimes the match challenges don't appear to count properly or are too literally applied, and it seems inconsistant with its application of what meets the requirements of a given challenge. For example, I played a match that wanted me to get a 3 ball streak with a jump shot. I got a 4 ball streak with a jump at the end and it didn't count it. The next time I played, it seemed to count it. So I just don't trust the AI at all. Also, some of the designer ball sets that you can unlock confuse me visually because the stripes and solids look too similar to me from a distance. The settings are very colorful, which isn't necessarily bad, but can be VERY loud.

Anyway, even though this seems a negative review, it's not meant to be. The devs say they are working to improve it, and if they do I think it has a lot of potential. As it is, if you can get it for a very low price and you like pool, try it. I've enjoyed playing it, but it can be frustrating at times.

reviewText:
First off, this is the best looking pool game I have ever played.  Period.
Beautiful pool tables, balls, and environments that are fully fleshed out and animated to give you a real sense of immersion.

The game is full of details that kept surprising me.  Some of them are so subtle that you can't even notice it unless you are watching the replay.  Here are a few things you will find:

* 3rd dimension: this isn't a simple pool game where balls stick to the table.  All pool balls can be knocked off, up in the air, and over other balls (given enough force).
* When hit certain ways, chalk will fall off stick and sprinkle on the table.
* Tiny woven texture on table material when you zoom in close
* Sides of table (bumpers) actually give and bend in when a ball hits them with force (very hard to notice without replay!)

For single player there is enough to keep you busy for awhile with tournaments in various game types against different AI.  One thing I found keeping my interest is bonuses you can try for on each game in a tournament.  For instance one might have a bonus for pulling off a jump shot during the match.  You can still win the game, but there will be a bonus for doing the jump shot.  Earning these stars while winning makes for a fun challenge.
There are also many ball styles, cue sticks, and locations to unlock through single player.  So far every ball set I have unlocked has been great looking and is a good incentive to keep playing and unlock more.

For multiplayer, it is fully functional in both same computer and online play.  Unsurprisingly you have to wait awhile for a game to show up, but that's less the fault of the game and more of the popularity of online pool :).

Last I should go over the physics.  This is a tough point to argue because so many factors go into pool physics and without a doubt there is no game out there that is 100% accurate.  If you have ever seen a ball hit another ball at high speed in close up slow motion you'll see what I mean.  Not to mention there are many different ball sizes/weight, table materials and cue sticks used in different areas that add to the difficulty in comparing this to the real world.

All I can say for sure is the physics seem real and have been really fun.  Added to the ability to hit the ball just where I want at power levels I never could in RL the game makes you feel like a pool master.

Game is on sale for $1.99 currently.  Sell a couple summer trading cards and pick it up!

reviewText:
Recommended.

Depending on what you're looking for the single player campaigns are lacking.  There are a lot of opponents but they felt very identical to play against.  However, I wasn't working towards the challenges against each opponent and going for those could be fun, although they're usually pretty same-y (x match score, x-ball streak).  Additionally, there are actual stand-alone challenges but of the few I played they were pretty boring.  While they did break up gameplay when I found it necessary, the AI is so unpredictable  that modes like speed challenge or 3 ball just aren't that much fun.

As a 8-Ball and 9-ball simulator, though, this game is pretty excellent.  The physics work, there's a guiding shot marker to help  you learn how to shoot better (this can also be turned off, or reduced) and the game is pretty.  Pool Nations ia  large step up from those crappy flash games.

Online play seems functional.  At the very least I didn't have any issues with it.  For online play there are a lot of interesting game modes past 8 and 9 ball including 3 ball, straight, rotation, speed, and killer.  Of those I only tried killer (possibly speed in the campaign) and it was fun, though it felt more like a quick distraction between a few rounds of 8 ball.

So yes, I recommend this game.  It's much, much better for me than driving down to the Pool Hall, especially when I can't guarantee I'll have anyone to play.  This is something I needed in my life and it's nice to have, but I also recognize that it's probably not for everyone.  I've only played a handful of times and only for a few hours total.  It's definitely a pick up and play for a few rounds and then put it down for a few weeks kind of game, though that is exactly what I wanted.

Oh, and I guess there are features that haven't been implemented yet but are on their way like the box of tricks.  That mode seems fairly interesting.

reviewText:
Extremely fun game!
Pool Nation has a very realistic physics engine, with very nice graphics. There is a ton of achievements to be unlocked and replayability is great.

There are, however, a few problems with this game:
a) If you simply want a quick game, it isn't so quick, because there are lots of menus to go through, and the cutscenes before the game starts are painfully long.
b) the graphics are great, beautiful, but some of them very unrealistic when it comes to pool tables. The developers did a great job exploring the rendering engine they had in hand, but I believe there was no need for so many fancy and colored pool tables and balls. IMHO, a pool table has to be green. Forget about everything else, because it just gets in the way of the game.

Neverthless, Pool Nation is a great game, worth every penny. I am not afraid to say it is possibly the best pool game ever made, and the closest thing to a pool/billiard/snooker simulator.

If the developers ever read this, I have a suggestion: make it possible to create custom game rules, like we do in real life.

reviewText:
This game really caught my eye on steam, and how could it not, it‚Äôs so very very shiny. Released originally on PSN Cherry Pop ported their billiards game over to the PC and is available for $10 via steam.

What we have here is really a modern pool game. A sparkling beautiful graphics engine combined with an impressive realistic physics engine all to send shiny balls flying around a table. It‚Äôs smooth, it‚Äôs pretty, it‚Äôs gorgeous. (click on some of my high-res screenshots and see for yourself!) Really what else do you need to know? If you like pool games then it‚Äôs for you, if you don‚Äôt, all the shiny graphics in the world probably won‚Äôt change your mind. What you might expect from a pool game is all here, an 8-ball and 9-ball tour to play through with slowly increasing difficulty as well as some other game modes to throw in some variety.

There are also arbitrary points systems that award you points based upon added difficulty of shots (kinda like the way skater games give you points for harder tricks) and as you progress through each tour there are challenges to meet in each match to unlock extra goodies. It‚Äôs all your typical completionist fluff we‚Äôve grown to expect from games these days but they do add some extra challenge and drives you to try to be more creative as you play. I also found I enjoyed most of the challenge modes that are unlocked during the tour play although a couple get a little tedious and boring.

Everything in the game is well crafted, the table is high textured, the balls well polished and reflective, and even the backgrounds are rich with detail and eye candy. The art style is beautiful and there‚Äôs even interesting little blurbs written about each opponent you play against. But all of this eye candy is just background noise to distract you from pocketing those balls! The game really shines though when it comes to trick-shots. Jump shots, draw backs, kick shots, even riding the rail is all possible with the engine. With full control to put on as much english and angle on your shot as you‚Äôd like you can put together some pretty sweet shots. Thanks to the shot guides they are not very difficult to learn and once you start pulling them off with regularity your options with each shot open wide. Best of all, the AI knows and uses them just as well which creates quite a challenge as you progress through the game.

The trick-shots are definitely best seen in video as screenshots cannot do them proper justice. You‚Äôll be hopping over balls and making crazy draw backs in no time making you feel quite the awesome player. The game is, however, not without it‚Äôs flaws. A common complaint I have of many games, the music started to get annoying to me but this is not the first game I‚Äôve had to mute the music and play my own. It is also clear that it is a port rather than designed specifically for the PC.

The menus sometimes feel a bit awkward navigating with a mouse and I feel some of the controls are awkward. For example rotating my cue around the cue ball to line up a shot only involves moving mouse left or right, yet my natural inclination is to try to circle the mouse around the cue ball. It made for some very frustrating moments until I realized this. Also I found the video replay system to be- clunky at best. Still even with these small complaints I‚Äôd definitely recommend the game if you ever find yourself wanting to shoot some pool.

However, the amount of time it takes you to learn how to play with buttons (versus using an actual pool stick) is time that you also gain experience and tips; so realistically you are not losing anything but gaining more than you pay for!  Being taught how to play a sport (that can be used for real life) is so worth paying only a dollar for.  McDonald's doesn't even have a dollar menu anymore; it's like $1.50.  Though I was fortunate at the time and the game is back to its' original price, the pirce is $9.99 (NOT EVEN $10!!) so it's not too bad a price.

+Price: Cheap!!! :)

reviewText:
Very well done Pool game. I'm a long time Virtual Pool player (15+ years). Physics could be a teeny bit better, like the english (ball spin) physics. In real life, pockets on a pool table have angled cushions around the pocket to help your ball in, should you hit them correctly...In this game however, if you don't hit the ball straight into the pocket, it's not going in. If you hit the angled portion around the pocket, it will just reject your ball much of the time, really unforgiving but challenging. Hard to explain...think of a basketball hoop where if you didn't swish the ball, the ball would never go in.

I don't use that aim assist or flashback bullcrap either. That's for sissies!

Easy on the eyes and shiny as hell, though. I think the lighting on the balls (ha, balls) could be a lot better. Also, like the virtual pool series, it's a great game to play and mute all the in-game sound if you're in the mood to rock out to some of your mp3s, you can fully enjoy your music and the game at the same time.

The game is still in development so I think it will improve over time. There are few odd glitches here and there. Buy this game the next time it's on sale and come play with me!

reviewText:
This game is possibly the best pool game I've ever had the pleasure of playing. The sound design is fantastic, the graphics are shiny but non-intrusive, I haven't seen a single physics error. If you want to simulate a game of pool, this will do it almost to a tee.

However. I have three reservations.

The power meter gets stuck sometimes if the mouse is accidentally pulled to the edge of the window, even on fullscreen. This can cause some dodgy shots.
The Endurance challenge instruction page seems to be bugged and will only let you see the last page of it. To be fair, the gist of the 6 page manual is that you need to pot balls fast, but it's not entirely apparent what parameters there are on this activity.
The Straight challenge does not account for trick shots or indirect aiming the same way that the rest of the game is, and this is never explained. As such, and as the name might suggest, you should only shoot straight. No jumping, no swerving, don't even think about a combo.
Aside from that, a very robust and well designed pool game.

reviewText:
It's kinda tricky to review a Pool game so I will try and break it down into what matters.

Graphics
As you can see in the screenshots the game looks great, it is ported from the Xbox 360 so it will run pretty damn well on almost any computer set up you care to mention and with Anti-alising all the way up it is a very very nice game to look at. Gameplay
The Pool on display here is very nice. The balls all act realistically and as far as I can tell things like friction have been modeled very well. In the close up slow-mo shots you get sometimes when a ball is potted you can see that the balls are lifting up and sliding about realistically. The sound design helps to sell this as well, with nice clear sound making it all the more satisfying when the ball drops.

Multiplayer
As far as I can tell the multiplayer for this game is dead. Which is a shame and slightly confusing. I couldn't seem to find any games at all in any mode so unless one of your friends has the game it is most likely gonna be solo play for you.

Overall
Considering The lack of a decent Pool game on PC and the promise of the release of the Trick Shot mode soon I would say this game is well worth picking up

reviewText:
You can either play an hour and a half or so of real pool, or buy permanent access to probably the most polished pool game on pc for that price. This game looks and feels great, has infinite replayability value if you are into pool, and has some quite interesting features coming, inculding the free Box of Tricks DLC!
Controls may seem a bit overwhelming for the first 15 or so minutes, but you will get the hang of it pretty soon. After that, they feel great and pretty easy to use, considering what you are capable of doing in this game.
The only slight complain is that the menus were probably initially designed for gamepad use, and while mouse and keyboard works perfectly fine in them, there are some slightly weird leftovers, like the menu that appears when you are about to use a Flashback (The available choices are listed as 2 buttons of an Xbox 360 gamepad, but mouse works great here too). Keyboard keys are listed correctly everywhere else though. Really really small complain for an overall great title!
It happened to crashed 2 times, but considering my pc and its current state, I probably can't and won't blame it on the game itself. Luckily both times were during the initial loading, so no game was in progress.

Regarding multiplayer, you can play online with friends or other people, but I haven't found anyone in 2 quick searches. I however didn't try hosting a game due to limited time.
You can also play locally, with 2 players using different input methods, or hotseat (2 players using the same input method).

It's definitely worth your attention if you are interested in the sport, 9.7/10 and that is only because of the gamepad oriented GUI that is left in a few places.
Keep in mind that while I have only played 3 hours so far, I probably experienced most of the core mechanics, after all it is a pool game, not an MMORPG.

reviewText:
I love this game for 2 player local co-op.  We use 2 Steam Controllers and play via my Steam Link.

This is a fun little pool game that is great for players of all skill levels.  The controls are very intuitive and have been easily picked up by my 75 year old father and others.   We all like the music and find it contributes nicely to the overall relaxing nature of 2 player pool.

One of the great features is the versatile aiming aid which shows players the exact path of the cue ball and object ball as they aim and adjust spin and power.  As players get better they can shorten the length of the aid to increase the player skill required to make the shots.  In 2 player local co-op each player may choose the length of the aiming aid independent of the other player.  This means experts can have a very short aiming aid while less-experienced players may have a longer one.  This is a nifty way to handicap games that doesn't make new players feel pandered-to in my experience.

A couple of negatives are that the physics are a bit questionable at times, and the aiming aid can permit some absolutely ludicrous shots that would be impossible outside of a physics simulation.  The single player career seems to be nothing more than a way to purposefully gate content... even though you bought the game if you want all the locations and wingdings unlocked you have to buy the unlock" DLC or slog through the laborious and completely unfun "career".

All in all
date: I recommend this game for local co-op play and pretty much no other reason.  Several times I've checked out the online lobbies and couldn't find anybody to ever play with though YMMV."

This is a very nicely presented pool game, with everything that a fan of the game would want. It has nine-ball pool (pot the balls in sequence and whoever pots the last ball is the winner), eight-ball pool (the stripes and solids version), trick shots and online play.

Every match in the campaign mode has extra challenges that make each game different and help to ramp up the difficulty. For example, a challenge might be to get a four-ball streak, perform a kick shot, etc. There‚Äôs also a few bonus rounds with different modes of play.

Tutorials are excellent. It guides you through each step of the shot and makes it very easy to perform impressive stuff like kick shots, jump shots, combo shots, swerve shots and more. There's a surprisingly large amount of ways to hit a ball.

You can unlock different designs for the tables, cues and balls. You also unlock different locations to play pool in. These are purely cosmetic, but they look great and add to the overall experience.

If the idea of playing pool appeals to you - definitely get this. I personally have very minimal interest in pool, but it‚Äôs all so well done that I'm enjoying it anyway.

reviewText:
Pool Nation is a game about, well, pool. You hit balls, get them in the pots, battle against AI or online, and rage at your friends for their skill at games. But there are a few flaws in this that make the game's screenshots exagerate how the game actually is.

First of all, the physics in the balls are AWFUL. Atleast 20 times (not exageration) during my career I got the ball stuck RIGHT AT THE POT and it didn't go in. If we got it to atleast the edge, give us credit or something. It happens to everybody playing pool, but come on, you didn't have to make it THAT realistic. Besides, who has two extra fingers on each hand?

Second, the camera controls are amazingly crap. You MOVE YOUR MOUSE to move the camera. That's nice. How about when I'm trying to hit the ball? Can you KEEP THE CAMERA WHERE IT'S AT????? Half the time I'm trying to fix my camera or looking down the cue or I'm a 500 feet tall man that looks on the very top of the pool table.

Last, the AI in this game is the hardest I've ever played. If you don't hit a ball, this AI will hit every striped/coloured ball it sees and you realise that you should use your time wisely because he hit all the balls, he's ready to hit the 8 ball, and you have to hurry and hit all your balls. It took me 3 times to beat the first guy. THE FIRST GUY. I have played pool as well, and I've went through the tutorial.

My honest review is that if this game is on sale, don't get your hopes too high but you could buy it. If it's at it's regular $10 price, it's not worth your money.

What a fantastic Pool Game! It¬¥s been a while since I played a real game of Pool and it¬¥s been even longer since I played a Pool game on a PC.
I got Pool Nation in a Bundle and did not expect too much, but this Game (or should I call it a Simulation) is just brilliant.
The first thing one might notice are the visuals. The environments are beautifully crafted, as are the tables. The lighting is superb (although a little bit less bloom would have been nice), the textures (especially of the balls and the cloth) are very highly detailed. And you can even see the chalk coming off in the slow motions you get sometimes when you make a great shot.
And the balls have nice, realistic looking reflections which only adds to the atmosphere.
One might think that the background tune is repetetive, but I did not feel that yet. It fits perfectly to the environments and it really wants to make you step into your screen, right into that room and have a very nice, calm and relaxing game of Pool.

Now to the physics: When I played first, I played through the tutorial which was a good choice. I would not have expected that the cue / ball interaction is modeled that well. You can do whatever I can think of in real life with the cue and land all kind of Trick shots. It seems there¬¥s even a (free?) DLC in the works which focuses on Trick shots, and I¬¥m really looking forward to it.

You can attend several tournaments with different rules (there¬¥s 8-ball, 9-ball and lots of other play styles you can choose from) and there¬¥s Multiplayer which I did not try yet. I want to play through all the single player Tournaments first to get some practice.

And the difficulty? Well, it¬¥s partly up to you. You can select between various levels of how the game helps you to visually see in which directions the balls will roll. This is also great to teach you what kind of effects a shot by aiming the cue in specific angles to the white ball will have before you even shoot.

I can only highly recommend Pool Nations and I don¬¥t see anything another Pool game could make better.

If you can get it on sale, definitely get it. It's a good pool sim, but I wouldn't say the best. It has some little things that irk me especially having played other pool games like Virtual Pool, and of course real life pool (in which I suck lol).

The graphics are beautiful, though at times it may be a little too shiny, like everything is made of chrome. With some balls it's difficult to distinguish between the stripes and the solids due to how the light shines on them at some angles. It also has a tendency for the FPS to shoot up too much if you have a decent gaming rig, so be sure to use VSync or have some kind of frame limiter program like RTSS. The problem with the FPS shooting up is that it makes it harder to aim as how quickly the mouse moves is affected by it. There are no advanced graphics options adjustments except for VSync and anti-aliasing. An option to reduce shininess or even brightness/gamma would've been great.

Cue and ball control are fairly good. It may take some getting used to how noticeably slow the rails and the table are if you're coming from other pool games. The speed of the table and whatnot are not adjustable in this game. However, they feel somewhat similar to real life pool tables so that's not a bad thing. The only other odd thing I've noticed is that the side pockets are very open. You can pocket shots into them from angles that you just can't do in real life. Pocket size can't be adjusted either.

reviewText:
Realistic game of pool, sounds great and the physics are nice.
There's different camera views, you have a top down mode for when you need to look at the entire table for extreme accuracy, and a first-person? (not sure what to call it) mode and it feels great to play in, like you're really at a pool table playing.
They even have slow-mo cams that zoom in to the ball when you've shot one in
(only happens once in a while so it's not annoying and you can skip it if you want by pressing the button for skipping; you can even choose to skip the turns the npc takes when you want to play against them).

Singleplayer has different modes,
and you can play against npcs in several types of games (while sometimes unlocking different designs for the cue, ball, or the table as rewards for certain things).
There's 'free mode' where you can just play by yourself without a limit (if you just want to shoot while relaxing or try out certain moves).
There's also an endurance mode, which is like free mode (the by yourself without npc aspect), but is timed or rather the goal is to shoot as many balls in as you can, as fast and accurate as you can before too many extra balls get added to the table.
And they have a tutorial mode where you can learn how to play and learn advanced tricks.

You can turn the guiding 'lines' completely off, for people who want to play real-world style;
they're just like training wheels and you can choose to use them or not,
and you can also choose to have the lines, but have different types, if you want.

The npcs aren't perfect shots, but they're not terrible either,
and sometimes they'll miss after perfectly shooting 4-ball in a row or something, for example;
it's a bit random, kinda like a real person might miss, even if they're good.

There's plenty of content to play,
challenges in the game that unlock bonus rounds, new areas and npc characters,
or reward you with a design for the cue, ball, or table, that you can use to play with.
And of course there's still the steam achievements.
Or you can try to master the advanced tricks from the tutorial and try them in free mode and then later against npcs.
You can also repeat maps you've played already (when you unlock something it gets unlocked for permanent use).

Some games I regret buying, but this is definitely not one of them.
If you like pool games, this is a nice one to have
